verses.text: Better a poor man who walks with integrity than one who is crooked in speech and is a fool.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the virtue of integrity over wealth and clever words. The wisdom tradition favors moral uprightness, foreshadowing Christ's beatitudes. The spiritual life puts righteousness above earthly gain.

verses.text: Desire without knowledge is not good, and whoever hurries his feet slips.
verses.comment: Highlights the need for both zeal and wisdom. In spiritual matters, knowledge guides desire toward true good. This resonates with the biblical call to study and ponder God's law.

verses.text: A person’s own foolishness ruins his way, yet his heart rages against the LORD.
verses.comment: The verse teaches personal responsibility; we suffer for our errors yet are tempted to blame God. A tacit call to humility and trust in divine providence, critical in Christian life.

verses.text: Wealth brings many friends, but the poor are left by their companion.
verses.comment: Worldly status changes relationships. True friendship is spiritual, echoing Christ’s teaching to care for the needy, reflecting the value of selfless love.

verses.text: A false witness will not go unpunished, and the one who breathes out lies will not escape.
verses.comment: Truthfulness is demanded by God’s law. Here, divine justice is underscored, setting a foundation for Jesus' later emphasis on truth and integrity (John 8:44, about liars, and truth in Christ).

verses.text: Many seek the favor of a generous man, and everyone is a friend to a giver of gifts.
verses.comment: Reiterates superficiality of worldly favor. Looks ahead to Christ’s teaching on giving with a pure heart, not seeking reward (Matthew 6:1-4).

verses.text: All the relatives of the poor hate him; how much more do his friends stand far off! He pursues them with words, but they are gone.
verses.comment: Shows how poverty isolates. Calls for compassionate love—which is elevated in the Christian call to love those excluded by society.

verses.text: Whoever gains wisdom loves his own soul; he who keeps understanding will find good.
verses.comment: Pursuing wisdom is an act of self-love properly ordered, echoing the biblical command to love one’s neighbor as oneself (Lev. 19:18; Matt. 22:39).

verses.text: A false witness will not go unpunished, and the one who speaks lies will perish.
verses.comment: Repeats v.5, underscoring the certainty of divine justice for lying. The serious consequence of falsehood anticipates Jesus’ condemnation of deceit.

verses.text: It is not fitting for a fool to live in luxury—how much less for a servant to rule over princes.
verses.comment: Social order matters in biblical wisdom; here, disorder is seen as unnatural. Spiritually, disorder in the soul brings harm, echoing Paul’s exhortation for order in the church.

verses.text: A person’s understanding makes him slow to anger, and it is his glory to overlook an offense.
verses.comment: Christian life calls for mercy and patience, following the example of God’s patience and Christ’s forgiveness, encouraging the faithful to look past minor faults.

verses.text: The king’s wrath is like the roar of a lion, but his favor is like dew on the grass.
verses.comment: Highlights the need for respect of authority. In Christian tradition, kingship points to Christ the King, whose favor brings life (John 4:14).

verses.text: A foolish son is ruin to his father, and a wife’s quarrels are a continual dripping.
verses.comment: Family harmony is precious. Echoes teaching on the importance of faithfulness and mutual respect within the household, foundational for Christian living.

verses.text: House and wealth are inherited from fathers, but a prudent wife is from the LORD.
verses.comment: Material inheritance is earthly, but true blessings—like a wise spouse—are gifts from God. Points to the sacramental nature of marriage as a divine institution.

verses.text: Laziness brings deep sleep, and a slothful person will go hungry.
verses.comment: Industriousness is rewarded in both material and spiritual life. Scripture calls us to diligence in faith, echoing Paul’s words to ‘run the race’ (1 Cor. 9:24).

verses.text: Whoever keeps the commandment preserves his life; he who despises his way will die.
verses.comment: Fidelity to God’s instruction leads to life. This points to obedience to the full counsel of God as necessary for salvation, a teaching Christ reaffirms.

verses.text: Whoever is generous to the poor lends to the LORD, and He will repay him for his good deed.
verses.comment: Charity is presented as lending to God himself, reflected in Christ’s identification with the poor. Spiritual almsgiving is especially meritorious.

verses.text: Discipline your son while there is hope, but do not set your heart on his destruction.
verses.comment: Godly discipline is loving, aimed at correction not harm. Reflects God’s own loving discipline of us, as explained in Hebrews 12.

verses.text: A person with great anger will bear the penalty, for if you rescue him, you will only need to do it again.
verses.comment: Repeated rescue of the habitually angry does not solve the root problem; wisdom tradition urges spiritual transformation rather than enabling vice.

verses.text: Listen to advice and accept instruction, that you may gain wisdom in the future.
verses.comment: Humility before wise counsel is a mark of spiritual maturity. Scripture upholds tradition as wisdom passed on, a subtle reflection of the value of received faith alongside Scripture.

verses.text: Many are the plans in a man’s heart, but it is the LORD’s purpose that prevails.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty over human plans highlights the necessity of submitting one’s will to divine guidance. Spiritually, this calls for unity with God's will, as modeled by Christ.

verses.text: What is desired in a man is steadfast love, and a poor man is better than a liar.
verses.comment: Faithfulness and love are prized above wealth. Echoes the primacy of charity in Christian faith (1 Cor. 13:13).

verses.text: The fear of the LORD leads to life; one rests satisfied and will not be touched by harm.
verses.comment: True reverence for God brings spiritual life and peace, and ultimately salvation. Theologically, this prepares the soul for the fullness of God’s promise.

verses.text: The sluggard buries his hand in the dish and will not even bring it back to his mouth.
verses.comment: Exaggerates laziness for effect; spiritual sloth is equally dangerous. Our faith must be active, not passive; so too with grace and works.

verses.text: Strike a scoffer, and the simple will learn prudence; reprove the wise, and he will gain knowledge.
verses.comment: Discipline is a tool to instruct both the foolish and the wise; openness to correction is a spiritual asset.

verses.text: Whoever robs his father and drives out his mother is a son who brings shame and disgrace.
verses.comment: Dishonor to parents is grave, contradicting the commandment to honor father and mother. This is foundational to both family and spiritual authority.

verses.text: Cease to listen to instruction, my son, and you will stray from words of knowledge.
verses.comment: Continual reception of instruction is necessary to remain in wisdom and truth. This affirms the value of ongoing, faithful teaching and tradition in spiritual growth.

verses.text: A worthless witness mocks justice, and the mouth of the wicked gulps down evil.
verses.comment: Perverting justice is abhorrent. Spiritual application: the need to uphold the truth and defend the innocent is central to the virtuous life.

verses.text: Condemnation is ready for scoffers, and blows for the backs of fools.
verses.comment: Judgment awaits those who reject wisdom. Scripture repeatedly warns of consequences for rebellion, urging repentance and conversion.
